lines.text: [first lines]

[voice over narration]
What could be more symbolic of America than the modern American schoolgirl? Intelligent, restrained, dignified and...
Miss Ingraham, I'd much rather start my real art classes.
My Goodness, there wasn't a nicer accomplishment for a woman than china painting. Gives you such a good foundation.
But I've got a foundation. I've been painting at home for years.
Let me see now, I... I don't know exactly where else I'd put you.
Oh, what about the live class.
Oh, that's much more advanced. Next year perhaps. I take the girls out myself in the country once a week, and we all do a landscape. Cows, trees. There's some charming sycamores not far away.

Miss Ingraham, I'm afraid we just don't understand each other. I mean a life class, the human figure. Rembrandt said it is the basis of all design, all structure. That's what I need. My anatomy's terrible.
The human figure. You mean unclothed?
Certainly.
Oh! Miss Sheldon! Oh! Miss Sheldon, I want to have a talk with you. Go into my office.

If you'll kindly consent to read this you'll notice it's about an art competition. There are three prizes of fifty dollars. I intend to win one of those prizes painting a portrait of you as a spirit of labor.
Are you bats?
Dinah, I don't like you being expelled. Miss Ingraham's right, immorality takes many forms.
Yes, Papa.
I wonder what else went on in that hidden little studio.
Well I've heard about artists.
Now will you please go away.
No question. You need red there in the middle on the nose.
That nose is okay.
I don't wish to disagree with you Mack, but I seen much a painting, and the way that is, it ain't no good.
Looks good to me. Ain't that right?
That's right.
Looks like you're wrong, Beau.
My dear Sir, when I'm wrong I'll let you know. That nose ain't no good without more red. See?

[paints Beau's nose red]
Is that enough red for you?
Gentlemen, now please. Stop that, please gentlemen.
[last lines]
Sit down, sit down. Bring up another chair.
